transcript:
Therapist: As we wrap up our discussion on self-care, I want to emphasize the importance of consistency and self-compassion. Incorporating small self-care activities into your daily routine may feel challenging at first, but with practice, it will become more natural. Remember to be patient with yourself and celebrate the small victories along the way.

Patient: I appreciate the reminder to be patient and self-compassionate. It's easy for me to get frustrated with myself when I don't meet my own expectations, but I'm working on being kinder to myself.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear, Marcus. Developing self-compassion is a crucial part of the healing process. As we near the end of our session today, I'd like to check in on your current mood and any final thoughts you'd like to share.

Patient: I'm feeling a bit tired, but also hopeful. Our discussions today have given me some new perspectives and strategies to work with. I know it won't be easy, but I'm committed to putting in the effort to challenge my negative beliefs and prioritize my well-being.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you're feeling hopeful and committed to the process. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there will be ups and downs along the way. What matters most is that you keep showing up for yourself and reaching out for support when needed.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I appreciate your support and guidance throughout this process.

Therapist: Before we end our session, let's discuss your homework for the coming week. I'd like you to continue practicing the thought records and behavioral activation techniques we've been working on. Additionally, I encourage you to start implementing the self-care activities we discussed today, such as taking a short walk during your lunch break and setting aside time to unwind in the evening. Pay attention to how these activities impact your mood and overall well-being, and feel free to adjust them as needed.

Patient: That sounds good. I'll make a note of the homework and do my best to stick with it.

Therapist: Great. If you encounter any challenges or have any insights you'd like to share, feel free to bring them up in our next session. We can also continue exploring the core belief of worthlessness and work on reframing it in a more balanced and compassionate way.

Patient: I appreciate that. I'm sure I'll have plenty to discuss next time.

Therapist: I look forward to hearing about your experiences and progress. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That means a lot to me.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Exploration of the core belief of worthlessness and its impact on thoughts and behaviors
  - Strategies for prioritizing self-care and finding balance between work and personal well-being
  - Challenging cognitive distortions related to self-care, such as "should statements"

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Downward arrow technique to uncover the origins of the core belief of worthlessness
  - Evidence-based thinking to challenge negative thoughts about self-care
  - Scheduling self-care activities and creating a realistic self-care plan
  - Thought records and behavioral activation (continuing from previous sessions)

- Homework assigned:
  - Continue practicing thought records and behavioral activation techniques
  - Implement self-care activities discussed in the session, such as taking a short walk during lunch and setting aside time to unwind in the evening
  - Pay attention to the impact of self-care activities on mood and overall well-being

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Patient reported small improvements in mood and outlook since the last session
  - Challenges with consistency in implementing therapy techniques and prioritizing self-care
  - Depression symptoms continue to include feelings of worthlessness, anxiety, and negative thoughts about work performance and self-worth

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Identified early experiences contributing to the core belief of worthlessness
  - Discussed the influence of parental pressure and perfectionism on the development of this belief

- Important information to carry forward to future sessions:
  - Continue monitoring patient's progress with thought records, behavioral activation, and self-care techniques
  - Explore core beliefs and intermediate beliefs related to worthlessness and perfectionism in more depth
  - Consider introducing additional CBT techniques as appropriate, such as cognitive restructuring or experiments to test beliefs

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review patient's experience with the homework assignments, including thought records, behavioral activation, and self-care activities
  - Discuss progress, challenges, and any new insights or questions that have come up since the last session
  - Continue exploring the core belief of worthlessness and work on reframing it in a more balanced and compassionate way
  - Collaboratively create a new weekly schedule incorporating self-care activities and behavioral activation techniques
